title: How many worker protests will the China Labor Bulletin record from 1 May 2016 to 1 November 2016?
preds: The CLB reports roughly 180-200 protests a month in 2016, since peaking at over 500 in January. The CLB would need to report 230 or so incidents in October to reach a number over 1200. This is possible but not in line with the recent trend.
To exceed 1200 there would have to be 237 protests in October.  So far there's been only 65.  It seems highly unlikely that there would be 172 protests in the last 7 days of the month.
By my count Total May - September = 963, so >236 necessary to reach 1,200.   Incidents for Oct so far (10/26) is 65.  Since May the highest monthly count was 209, therefor >236 v. unlikely.

https://www.ft.com/content/56afb47c-23fd-3bcd-a19f-bddab6a27883 numbers to june 2016
http://maps.clb.org.hk/strikes/en numbers to oct 2016 (and grossly underreported imo)
Looked at China Labor Bulletin from 2015, seems like it was around 1200 for that time frame last year. Without knowing anything else, I predict it will be about the same.
Passage of time and no surprises yet.
Very low numbers still coming in for october.

Just keeping below consensus, likelyhood is strongly that will come in just below 1200. Pattern for Sept looking very like Oct at this stage.
http://maps.clb.org.hk/strikes/en
info starting to come for Oct. I think we can be reasonably certain that Sept is now 177.
Nearly at mid-October - most Sept data should have been entered by but may not have been yet, since none entered for Oct yet.

CLB now up to 960 strikes from May 1 to September 30. Updated to 177 for September. I'll have to keep an eye on this, because only 240 more strikes are needed to reach 1200. If the number for September continues to be updated, and the October number is similar, it could reach 1200.
Just staying with consensus for now. Data for Oct seems to be following same pattern as in Sept.

Number for Sept has crept a lot higher than expected (Currently 177) so lowering slightly. It is obvious now  that reporting at beginning of SEpt was delayed for some reason. Now have 17/18 entries for 1st Sept. Currently magic number for Oct is 240.

934 total recorded May -September.  That's about 187/month.  Based on these numbers there would have to be a 50% increase in October over the monthly average for the previous five months in order to surpass 1,200.   In addition monthly totals have been trending downward since July.  Looking at this another way, if October sees the same number as the highest month for the May -September time period (209), that still puts us at 1,143 (well under the 1,200 threshold).

Update: 4/10 
May 201 
June 169 
July 209 
Aug 204 
Sept 134 (probably will go to around 140)
This leaves about 275 for Oct to be below 1200. Last October was 230.
134 strikes  in September. 917 since May 1. One month to go. I'd be surprised if October has more than 200 strikes. Not enough.

898 results found to date, at that rate it would be unlikely to even hit 1 000, 1,200 is unlikely. Clearly labour unrest is not a significant factor.
http://maps.clb.org.hk/strikes/en

If my math is correct for 2016;  May through September =898
To reach 1200 an additional 302 reports would be required (delayed September +October)  According to 
@Raisinville http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/338236 there is minimal delay in finalizing previous months' reports so September numbers probably close to final count.   (lower than Sept 2015 @ 227).    
 October 2016 therefor unlikely to reach 302, since there is an overall declining trend and Oct 2015 reported only 230 strikes.

Given @Raisinville's meticulous study of history and given the recent change in personnel at the CLB ...
http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/338236 We would need 208 in September, and 209 in October. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n9aYrURLHh0

In  the last two days, the number for September jumped from 69 to 102. Some kind of backlog? More to come? Moving back to my previous forecast for now.

Looks like September will be very low numbers so leaves a lot of room for Oct to hit 300 and still be under 1200.
http://maps.clb.org.hk/strikes/en

There are 834 worker protests as of today, but the instructions in the More Info for finding the number are wrong. The CLB Strike Map filters by one month "to" another month, not "through" another month. If you filter 2016-5 to 2016-10, you only get 5 months. You want to filter 2016-5 to 2016-11. in 2015 and 2014, the number of strikes increased in the fall, but it doesn't seem to be this year. Only 51 strikes so far in September.
Passage of time, low Sept numbers
Today , at this pace, we should attain 87 % of 1200 the first november 2016

Trending has been just under 200 on average for the previous seven months.  For us to get over 1,200 in the period of this proposition, we would have to see one or both of the upcoming months to be larger than any in the previous six months.   Things are close to 1,200, but I see no reason to assume we will see a significant increase that will lead to a number larger than 1,200.

Raising <1200 from 45% to 55%.

and number from monday (which contribute about 20% number's week) for the week starting 28 are also low.

The overall trend in 2016 is up from 2015

June     - 9
Last year Sept - Nov were all above 200 - will probably be the key period for this question...  watching with interest!

Wal-Mart workers back on the job (for now).
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-walmart-china-idUSKCN0ZN26C
May June total: 369 (so far).

July news: http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d1dd7376-4408-11e6-9b66-0712b3873ae1.html#axzz4DpqPRquP
http://finance.yahoo.com/news/striking-wal-mart-workers-china-092227233.html
Walmart staff across China start wild cat strikes over work hours (although the story only lists 3 incidents to date). 
Main issue is "flexible scheduling of an unlimited number of hours a day totaling up to 174 hours a month, with no overtime pay." 
Not sure how big an issue this will be since 174 / 8 indicates 22 eight hour work days a month, which, in the US is standard. So the issue is the distribution of the hours across the month. Slightly raising the forecast for the 1,200 - 2,000 bucket until the extent of future strikes can be better estimated.  As of 7/8/16 the "Strike Map" lists the following 3 Wal-Mart incidents: 7/1- Store 5782, 7/2- Store 2039, 7/4-Store 0209. June 2016 total protest count (and change history - due to updates):

So far no obvious increase since last year for May and early June numbers.

I find something interesting about those numbers coming from China Labor Bulletin: «I doubt that’s what’s happening here, though, for two reasons. One, other sources have reported the Chinese government has actually gotten more aggressive about censoring reports of social unrest in the past two years, so if anything we should expect the selection bias from that process to bend the trend in the opposite direction. Two, theory derived from historical observation suggests that strike activity should increase as the economy slows and the labor market tightens, and the observed data are consistent with those expectations. So, while the CLB data are surely incomplete, we have reason to believe that the trends they show are real.» [1]
With all my respect to this blogger, i'm not convinced about the causal relation between economic slow and striking activity. 
Whatever, my comments, i envy his thoughtful analysis.
[1] https://dartthrowingchimp.wordpress.com/2015/05/

Since 2011 there is a positive tendency, so i will think this year will be positive too (is it because there is really more worker protest or because there is more person who counted it...i cannot know).
If we take
the average of two last year... 2015 & 2014 / 2 = 1039
the same number as last year 2015 for the period = 1209
2015 * the average of increase for each month since 2011= 1460
y = 4,4405 - 41,644 for each month of the period= 1503,57
the average of increase annually for each month since 2011 (122%) * month of 2015= 2447
Roughly 200 per month now, with previous years indicating stable number over the summer while having a slow continuous increase between years. Leads to an estimate of 1.2k or slightly above.
Very few problems so far in June.

I'm not sure that China Labor Forecast really can record worker protest. This question is more about the capacity of this organization to do so than the real number of worker protest. If the budget or humans ressources are the same as last year, the number of protest should be nearly the same as last year whatever the real situation is.
currently on track for 978, based on 24 days worth of data
A slow start. But, reporting of worker strikes seems to lag behind real time. Still low numbers

Observations from the 1990s:
"... the most important mechanism of mobilization is the presence of coordinators or organizers ... Many of them do not have much experience in dealing with bureaucrats. Hence, [laid-off workers] need representatives who are able to negotiate with the government and ... initiators or organizers of .. collective action include current [small state-owned] entreprise leaders, previous entreprise cadres, retired workers, military veterans, non-cadre Party members and common workers. Most of them are ... more influential than the rank and file ... they are willing to become organizers [for] a combination of their personal stake in the action, community pressure, and some sense of justice. ... [and only after] if the whole [state-owned] entreprise goes bankrupt, closes production or ceases to pay its workers. Hence, many workers are affected simultaneously and consensus building among them is easier ... In contrast, workers who are laid off sequentially are often able to receive subsidies, because their entreprises are still in operation ... if the number of workers laid off each time is large, it is tantamount to simultaneous lay-offs ... " CAI: "The Resistance of Chinese Laid-Off Workers in the Reform Period", in: China Quarterly (2002). The article deals with the period of the 1990s, especially the period from 1998 to 2001, that was the period when China ended the lifetime employment in state-owned entreprises in the cities (as opposed to reforms in the countryside, earlier), to write-off "non-performing loans" and prepare for the WTO accession. Since then, we've seen (SARS) crisis, scandals, protests, econ downturns, ... and all article published since then sounded like China would implode and be wiped out from the face of the earth ... just in the next 72 hours. 
Meanwhile, ... tapping on a China-assembled smartphone.

Last year, based on the accepted source, there were 1207 such incidents in a similar period: 199 in May, 178 in June, 168 in July, 205 in August, 227 in September, and 230 in October. It's too early to say something about this year, but there was an increase in 2015, compared with 2014. More precisely, there were 704 incidents in the reference period in 2014. That is nearly a doubling. If the acceleration would hold, we should expect something like 2000+ incidents this year.
I don't expect a similar swelling, since 2015 was rather flat, but still I guess that there is still an element of novelty, and uptake will go up. I am centering my expectation at an average of 1800, until I see the first few months of 2016 data.

During prior years; the trend looks stable during the summer months, and overall the trend looks stable across 2015 and 2016 YTD, with the exception of the mid-winter spikes.  The early 2016 spike seems to be unique.
The 2016 data has already stabilized (April 2016) at 150 to 200 per month.
Base line forecast might be  between 800 and 1,200. The upward  trend from 2013 to 2015 seems to have stabilized across 2015 and 2016; however, un-certainty regarding the causes of  the spike in January, could lead to forecasting errors later.  Am also concerned that there are likely to be specific circumstances that invalidate the base rate, otherwise there would be no point to posting the question.

I have a two major concerns:
First, is China Labor Bulletin (CLB) will be able to take serious data considering that intelligence of this kind may be not available in the future. CLB is based on Hong Kong and recently we have been informed that some library have disappeared. 
Is this ONG with ties with North America can be closed before 2016? 
Are labour lawyers / organizers can be put in jail so strikes will fall?
Can labour laws are in the process to be adopt by local government so labour dispute would be more or less frequent?
Second matter
I am not sure that a slowing economy with a positive rate is something that can affect upward labour unrest.
Worker that doesn't have anymore work don't make strike. Worker who feared a layoff doesn't go in strike either.
I think that when there is inflation more worker are incline to make pressure to live better.
Inflation seems to be in a positive tendency so i would be incline to think that there will be more labour dispute.
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/china/inflation-cpi/forecast
Also, overall, if China's economy is not already at the maximum of his potential of medium and large enterprise i expected that there will be more possibility of labour dispute: more medium and large enterprise = more labour dispute. 
Security and health are also big issues for worker. When we see something happening in the explosion of Tianjin and that we all know that China is very industrialize, there will be more workers making protest.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_Tianjin_explosions So i don't think that there will be less labour dispute than last year.

initial forecast. I count 1208 over the same period last year, with the year-on-year trend increasing, and 1721 between 1st November 2015 and 20th April 2016. My rough guesstimate is that around the 2k mark is probably most likely, unlikely to be very substantially lower or higher.

This largely depends on CLB's capacity to find and record; not on how many incidents actually happen. In other words, we're predicting an organization's ability. This is akin to whether Apple would sell X amounts of iPhones by date Z. A 200-incidents-per-month average rate implies a capacity to find and identify six incidents a day. Today, it's the 117th day of the year and they have around 900 incidents, that is 900/117 = 8 incidents per day. In an NGO-like four hours workday, that's two incidents per hour. Suppose there would be a CLB robot working 7-days for 4 hours that finds <COL1> incidents, you get <COL1 * 214 days + 900> 2	1328
3	1542
4	1756
5	1970
6	2184
7	2398
8	2612
9	2826
10	3040
15	4110
20	5180
35	8390
30	7320 I vaguely remember a China Quarterly articles reporting on the 1990s incidence rates of worker protests; gut memory tells me 3000-5000 is a low bar for a year, or somewhat appropriate for half a year's count.  The difference between 8 incidents a day, and 10 incidents a day already gets you from one forecasting bin into the other.

The overall pattern of protests is a somewhat gradual increase until October of last year, followed by a sudden spike until January, followed by a decline to the present.  Here are some estimates, depending on if the number of protests/month
1. ...continues to decline at the same rate: less than 500 protests expected
2. ... is the same as the last month around 500 protests
3. ... is the same as the same month last year: around 1200 protests
4. ... increases at the same rate over the same month last year that last year's did: around 1700 protests
5. ... increases at the historical average rate over the same month last year: 3000 protests
6. ... is the same as the maximum month ever recorded, every month: 3000 protests I think 2 is probably the best assumption.  The most likely outcome  is fewer than 1,200 protests, and it seems very unlikely that there will be more than 5,000.

initial thoughts.  CLB article indicates large run-up in protests leading up to Chinese New Year, frequency reported has fallen off since then.  Only half of April in the map yet though - so looks like good chance of >200/month average, but also possible to fall below.  Over 3000 would represent more than double same time period in 2015, which had just over 1200 on the map.
CLB map is based on social media and is believed to capture 10-15% of protests.
